citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two medications being used to treat animals were expired. A bottle of Vetericyn had expired May, 2023. A bottle of
Therabloat, being used to treat bloat in goats, expired December, 2018. Expired medications can lose their effectiveness
and their ability to prevent or control disease and/or pain. The licensee must ensure that all medications and vaccines are
within their expiration dates at all times. TO BE CORRECTED BY APRIL 13, 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Several plants of Phytolacca americana, commonly known as pokeweed, were growing next to one of the lemur
enclosures. The lemurs would be able to reach through the chain-link fence of the enclosure to pick and possibly eat the
plants. Pokeweed is a toxic plant that can cause colic, mouth irritation, and diarrhea when eaten by a wide variety of
animal species. The licensee must remove these plants and establish an effective program of weed control. TO BE
CORRECTED BY APRIL 12, 2024.

Four baby goats were present in a cattle enclosure. They were then observed to crawl through an opening in the wire
fence back into the adjacent goat enclosure, which contained their mothers and other goats. Allowing this behavior could
result in injury from the wire or entrapment in the fence. The licensee must ensure that enclosures are structurally sound
and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. TO BE CORRECTED BY
APRIL 13, 2024.

In the Adventure Building, several mice were observed eating food waste below the Prevost's squirrel enclosure. The
bottom of the squirrel enclosure is wire, which allows the uneaten food to fall through to the concrete floor below. The
door to a small room adjacent to the squirrel enclosure was opened and several mice were observed. Mice can
contaminate food and water with their urine and feces and they can carry diseases that affect the health and well-being of
other species of animals. The licensee must establish and maintain a safe and effective program for the control of pests.
TO BE CORRECTED BY APRIL 16, 2024.

A Highland calf was missing the tips of both ears, leaving only about two-thirds of each ear remaining. The facility
representative stated that this calf had been bottle-raised in the same enclosure with other calves and that another calf
was observed sucking on this calf's ears. The behavior was not observed during the inspection and the ears had healed.
Allowing the calf's ears to be injured by another calf caused pain, discomfort, and disfigurement. The licensee must
separate animals as needed to ensure that animals are not allowed to harm each other, interfere with their health, or
cause discomfort. TO BE CORRECTED FROM THIS DATE FORWARD OF APRIL 11, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
ALICIA GRAVES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two medications being used to treat animals were expired. A bottle of Vetericyn had expired May, 2023. A bottle of 
Therabloat, being used to treat bloat in goats, expired December, 2018. Expired medications can lose their effectiveness 
and their ability to prevent or control disease and/or pain. The licensee must ensure that all medications and vaccines are 
within their expiration dates at all times. TO BE CORRECTED BY APRIL 13, 2024. 
3.84(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Several plants of Phytolacca americana, commonly known as pokeweed, were growing next to one of the lemur 
enclosures. The lemurs would be able to reach through the chain-link fence of the enclosure to pick and possibly eat the 
plants. Pokeweed is a toxic plant that can cause colic, mouth irritation, and diarrhea when eaten by a wide variety of 
animal species. The licensee must remove these plants and establish an effective program of weed control. TO BE 
CORRECTED BY APRIL 12, 2024. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Four baby goats were present in a cattle enclosure. They were then observed to crawl through an opening in the wire 
fence back into the adjacent goat enclosure, which contained their mothers and other goats. Allowing this behavior could 
result in injury from the wire or entrapment in the fence. The licensee must ensure that enclosures are structurally sound 
and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. TO BE CORRECTED BY 
APRIL 13, 2024. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
In the Adventure Building, several mice were observed eating food waste below the Prevost's squirrel enclosure. The 
bottom of the squirrel enclosure is wire, which allows the uneaten food to fall through to the concrete floor below. The 
door to a small room adjacent to the squirrel enclosure was opened and several mice were observed. Mice can

contaminate food and water with their urine and feces and they can carry diseases that affect the health and well-being of 
other species of animals. The licensee must establish and maintain a safe and effective program for the control of pests. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY APRIL 16, 2024. 
3.133  Critical
   
Separation. 
A Highland calf was missing the tips of both ears, leaving only about two-thirds of each ear remaining. The facility 
representative stated that this calf had been bottle-raised in the same enclosure with other calves and that another calf 
was observed sucking on this calf's ears. The behavior was not observed during the inspection and the ears had healed. 
Allowing the calf's ears to be injured by another calf caused pain, discomfort, and disfigurement. The licensee must 
separate animals as needed to ensure that animals are not allowed to harm each other, interfere with their health, or 
cause discomfort. TO BE CORRECTED FROM THIS DATE FORWARD OF APRIL 11, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ALICIA GRAVES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
